title: Complete Guide: Creating Self-Contained Tools in RCRT

content.summary: Comprehensive guide for creating tool.code.v1 self-contained tools in the RCRT system, including structure, schemas, permissions, secrets management, and upload process.

quick_start.overview: Self-contained tools are Deno-based, sandboxed tools defined as tool.code.v1 breadcrumbs. They execute in an isolated environment with explicitly declared permissions.
process: 1. Copy an existing working tool as a template (timer.json or echo.json)
2. Modify the code, schemas, and metadata
3. Validate the structure matches the schema
5. Verify it appears in the tool catalog

required_structure.description: Every tool.code.v1 breadcrumb MUST follow this exact structure
critical_rules: ✅ MUST have 'code' wrapper object with 'language' and 'source'
✅ MUST include required_secrets (array, even if empty)
✅ MUST include ui_schema (even if configurable: false)
❌ NEVER put 'source' directly in context (must be in code.source)
❌ NEVER use fields like 'runtime' or 'entry_point' (not in schema)
❌ NEVER forget the code wrapper - this is the #1 mistake

code_section.description: The code.source field contains your Deno TypeScript code

structure.export_function: export async function execute(input, context): Promise<Output>
structure.input_parameter: The input object, validated against input_schema

context_parameter.api: RCRT API methods (createBreadcrumb, searchBreadcrumbs, getBreadcrumb, getSecret)
context_parameter.request: Information about the tool invocation (request_id, trigger_event, etc.)
context_parameter.secrets: DO NOT USE - secrets should be loaded via context.api.getSecret()

best_practices: Always validate input at the start
Use context.api methods for RCRT interactions
Throw errors for invalid input or failures

input_schema.purpose: Defines what inputs the tool accepts

output_schema.format: JSON Schema describing the return value

permissions.description: Deno permissions control what the tool can access

available_permissions.net: Network access (true for all, false for none, or array of domains)
available_permissions.read: File system read (true/false or array of paths)
available_permissions.write: File system write (true/false or array of paths)
available_permissions.env: Environment variables (true/false or array of var names)
available_permissions.run: Run subprocesses (true/false or array of commands)

best_practices: Use net: true if tool needs RCRT API access
Use domain arrays for external APIs
Avoid write and run permissions unless absolutely necessary

secrets_management.philosophy: THE RCRT WAY - Never hardcode secret names, always reference by ID

wrong_way.description: ❌ NEVER do this - hardcoding secret names

right_way.description: ✅ ALWAYS do this - load secrets by ID from config
steps: 1. Tool config stores the secret breadcrumb ID (not the name)
2. Tool loads config using input.config_id or from tool.config.v1 breadcrumb
4. RCRT decrypts and returns the secret value

uploading_your_tool.description: How to upload your tool to RCRT using the breadcrumb-create tool

method_1_direct.description: Use breadcrumb-create tool to upload the definition

method_2_file.description: Save as JSON file and use bootstrap script
steps: 3. Restart tools-runner: docker compose restart tools-runner
4. Verify: docker compose logs tools-runner | grep yourtool

verification.check_database: Tool should appear in tool.code.v1 breadcrumbs
verification.check_dashboard: Tool should be visible in the dashboard UI

common_mistakes.description: Mistakes to avoid (learned from real experience)

mistakes.why: The Deno runtime expects code.source, not just source
Tool discovery looks for 'tool' tag, not 'tool:code'
RCRT principle: everything is a breadcrumb, reference by ID

mistakes.right: Always include, even if empty: required_secrets: [], ui_schema: { configurable: false }

mistakes.why: Deno runtime imports and calls the exported function

testing_your_tool.description: How to test your tool after upload
steps: 1. Check logs: docker compose logs tools-runner | grep yourtool
2. Verify in dashboard: Click on the tool, should show config UI
3. Create tool request: Use breadcrumb-create to create tool.request.v1
4. Watch for response: Check for tool.response.v1 with matching request ID
5. Debug errors: Check tools-runner logs for execution errors

calling_other_tools.description: Tools can invoke other tools by creating tool.request.v1 breadcrumbs

subscribing_to_events.description: Tools can subscribe to breadcrumb events (future feature)

bootstrap_execution.description: Tools can run automatically on startup

best_practices_summary: 1. Always start with a working tool template (echo.json or timer.json)
2. Use the correct structure: code.source, not just source
4. Load secrets by ID from config, never hardcode names
7. Validate all inputs at the start of execute()

☐ Output schema matches what execute() returns?
☐ Secrets loaded by ID, not by name?
